content:
The US government did acknowledge the civilian casualties and destruction caused by their own actions during the Vietnam War to some extent. However, the official narrative of the war often downplayed or dismissed civilian casualties as "collateral damage" caused by military operations against the communist forces.

In many cases, the US military and government denied responsibility for civilian casualties, claiming that they were caused by communist forces or by the "unfortunate consequences" of military operations. However, there were also instances in which the US government acknowledged and expressed regret for civilian deaths and damage to civilian infrastructure.

Despite this acknowledgement, the overall narrative of the war was heavily focused on blaming the communist forces for the suffering of civilians and the destruction of Vietnamese cities and villages. This narrative was intended to reinforce the US government's anti-communist stance and justify the continued American involvement in the war.

It is worth noting that the extent to which the US government acknowledged civilian casualties and destruction varied over time and depended on the political climate of the moment. In some cases, especially later in the war, the US government was more open about the unintended consequences of their military actions and more willing to take responsibility for them.
